title: IgA Vasculitis (HSP) with Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis in the Elderly
author: SZMC Geriatrics Department

data.title: IgA Vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein Purpura) with RPGN
data.subtitle: A Diagnostic Odyssey in a 78-Year-Old with Respiratory Compromise

data.title: Patient Introduction: Mr. Eli Ohayon
data.content:
Patient Overview
Eli Ohayon | 78-year-old Male | DOB: 25/08/1947

The "Respiratory Cripple" – Baseline Status (2018-2025)

  • Primary Phenotype: Chronic respiratory disease with recurrent exacerbations
  • Bronchiectasis: Structural lung damage with chronic mucus production
  • Steroid-Dependent Asthma: Severe asthma requiring chronic corticosteroid therapy
  • Occupational Exposure: History of turpentine/linseed oil exposure
  • Chronic Sinusitis: Prior FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery)

Historical Admissions Pattern

DatePresentationTreatment
May 2018Respiratory exacerbationIV antibiotics, steroids
July 2018Respiratory exacerbationIV antibiotics, steroids
February 2019Respiratory exacerbationIV antibiotics, steroids
September 2023Respiratory exacerbationIV antibiotics, steroids
Key Point: Through all these septic insults and aminoglycoside/contrast exposures, baseline creatinine remained stable at 1.1-1.2 mg/dL

data.title: The Infection That Changed Everything
data.content:
Mid-October 2025
Community-acquired respiratory infection triggers a cascade of autoimmune events

Initial Treatment

  • Antibiotics Administered:
    • Cefuroxime (Zinnat) – 2nd generation cephalosporin
    • Ceftriaxone (Rocephin) – 3rd generation cephalosporin
  • Clinical Response: Infection appeared to clear

The "Warning Shot" – October 29, 2025

ER Presentation
Instead of recovering, patient develops a new and ominous sign: Diffuse purpuric rash on lower extremities

Initial Assessment

FindingValueInterpretation
Rash TypePalpable PurpuraClassic for small vessel vasculitis
Creatinine1.21 mg/dLStill normal!
UrinalysisMicrohematuriaEarly warning sign

data.title: The Missed Signal: HSP Diagnosis
data.leftColumn:
October 30, 2025

Diagnosis: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP)

Clinical Features

  • Palpable purpura on lower extremities
  • No joint involvement documented
  • No abdominal pain
  • Preserved renal function

Discharge Treatment

  • Prednisone 20 mg daily
  • Follow-up arranged
data.rightColumn:
Critical Retrospective Analysis

The Missed Opportunity
Microhematuria was already present – indicating early renal involvement!

Why This Matters

  • Prednisone 20mg is adequate for cutaneous HSP
  • However, it may be insufficient for:
    • Renal HSP (IgA nephritis)
    • Prevention of RPGN progression

Guideline Consideration

  • HSP with renal involvement may require:
    • Higher dose steroids (1 mg/kg)
    • Earlier nephrology involvement
    • Close creatinine monitoring

data.title: The Catastrophic Return
data.content:
Admission: November 20, 2025
Three weeks after HSP diagnosis, the autoimmune pathology explodes

Presenting Symptoms

  • Chills (צמרמורת/Tzmarmoret)
  • Cloudy urine
  • Failure to thrive

The Shock: Laboratory Findings

ParameterOct 29 ValueNov 20 ValueChange
Creatinine1.21 mg/dL2.57 mg/dL↑ 112%
eGFR~55 mL/min24 mL/min↓ 56%
CRP—28.89 mg/dLMarked inflammation
Acute Kidney Injury: From baseline to AKI Stage 2 in less than 3 weeks!

data.title: The "Red Herring": UTI Diagnosis
data.content:
Urine Culture Results

OrganismClinical Significance
Pseudomonas aeruginosaGram-negative rod, often healthcare-associated
Enterobacter speciesGram-negative rod, opportunistic pathogen
Initial Working Diagnosis
Sepsis/Pyelonephritis with secondary AKI → Antibiotics initiated

The Clinical Conundrum: Plan vs. Reality

  • Expected: Treat infection → Inflammation resolves → Kidney function recovers
  • What Happened:
    DateCRPCreatinine
    Nov 2028.89 mg/dL2.57 mg/dL
    Nov 23↓ Improving2.78 mg/dL ↑
    Nov 245.24 mg/dL ↓3.63 mg/dL ↑
The Divergence: Infection markers improved while kidney function continued to worsen!

data.pathTitle: Why UTI Treatment Didn't Fix the Kidneys
data.trigger:
Two Separate Pathologies:
1. Bacterial UTI (Pseudomonas/Enterobacter)
2. Autoimmune glomerulonephritis (IgA deposition)
data.mechanism:
The Dissociation Explained:
• Antibiotics ✓ killed bacteria → CRP ↓
• Antibiotics ✗ do NOT stop IgA immune complexes
• Glomerular damage continued unchecked
• Creatinine continued to rise
data.effects:
• Progressive glomerular inflammation
• Crescent formation in glomeruli
• Rapid loss of filtration capacity
• Progression toward irreversible fibrosis
data.clinical:
• Rising creatinine despite infection control
• Persistent proteinuria and hematuria
• "Active sediment" in urinalysis
• Oliguria development
data.geriatricFactors:
Geriatric Challenges:
• UTI often triggers/unmasks underlying conditions
• Polypharmacy risk during treatment
• Age-related nephron loss compounds injury
• Slower recognition due to atypical presentations

data.title: The Diagnostic Pivot: From Sepsis to Glomerulonephritis
data.content:
Forcing the Question
The dissociation between improving infection and worsening kidney function demands a new diagnostic framework

The "Liquid Biopsy" – 24-Hour Urine Collection

ParameterResultInterpretation
Protein Excretion874 mg/24hSignificant proteinuria (nephrotic approaching)
Creatinine Clearance15.6 mL/minSeverely reduced GFR (CKD Stage 4-5)

Urinalysis: The "Active Sediment"

  • Heavy blood – glomerular source
  • Heavy protein – glomerular damage
  • RBC Casts – pathognomonic for glomerulonephritis!
Clinical Pearl: RBC casts form when red blood cells become trapped in the renal tubules within a protein matrix. They indicate active glomerular bleeding – not UTI!

data.title: The Immunological Smoking Gun
data.content:
Serology Panel Results

MarkerResultNormal RangeClinical Significance
IgA651 mg/dL70-400 mg/dLSTRONGLY suggestive of IgA Vasculitis!
IgE308 IU/ml0.5-180 IU/mlConsistent with atopic/asthma history
ANCANegativeNegativeRules out Wegener's/Microscopic Polyangiitis
ANANegativeNegativeRules out Lupus Nephritis
C3 / C4NormalNormalRules out Post-Strep GN, SLE
Anti-GBMNegativeNegativeRules out Goodpasture's Syndrome
Diagnosis Crystallizes
IgA Vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein Purpura) with Nephritis
Presenting as Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN)

ANCA, ANA, Anti-GBM, Complements, IgA

All Negative + Normal IgA:

data.algoEnd:
Mr. Ohayon's Profile:
ANCA ⊖ | ANA ⊖ | Anti-GBM ⊖ | C3/C4 Normal | IgA ↑↑
+ History of Palpable Purpura = HSP Nephritis

data.title: Imaging: The Pulmonary Component
data.content:
CT Chest – November 27, 2025

Finding
Ground Glass Opacities – raising concern for alveolar hemorrhage

Differential Diagnosis of Ground Glass + RPGN

ConditionLikelihood in This PatientReasoning
HSP with Pulmonary InvolvementMost LikelyFits clinical picture; IgA elevated
DAH (Diffuse Alveolar Hemorrhage)PossibleWould indicate severe vasculitis
Underlying Infection/PneumonitisPossibleHistory of respiratory disease
Goodpasture's SyndromeRuled OutAnti-GBM negative

Pulmonary-Renal Syndrome Consideration

  • Ground glass + RPGN = Pulmonary-Renal Syndrome
  • Classic triad: Hemoptysis + Renal failure + Systemic vasculitis
  • In HSP: Pulmonary involvement is rare but reported
  • Management: Same as renal HSP (immunosuppression)

data.title: The Hepatitis B Bombshell
data.content:
November 27, 2025 – A Major Barrier Emerges
Just as the team prepared for aggressive rescue therapy...

Events of November 27

  • Morning: Kidney biopsy performed to confirm crescentic GN
  • Afternoon: Immunology results flagged a critical finding

The Unexpected Discovery

TestResultInterpretation
Hepatitis B Surface Antigen (HBsAg)REACTIVEActive HBV infection or carrier state
Hepatitis B Core Antibody (Anti-HBc)NegativeUnusual pattern
Hepatitis B Surface Antibody (Anti-HBs)NegativeNo immunity
The Clinical Dilemma
RPGN requires high-dose pulse steroids to save the kidneys

BUT

Giving pulse steroids to a Hepatitis B positive patient risks fatal liver failure from HBV reactivation!

data.title: The Treatment Dilemma: Steroids vs. HBV Risk
data.leftColumn:
Renal Emergency

Without Treatment:
RPGN → End-Stage Renal Disease (weeks)

Why Pulse Steroids Are Critical

  • RPGN mechanism: Crescents forming in glomeruli
  • Crescents = Inflammatory cell infiltration
  • Untreated: Crescents → Fibrosis → Permanent damage
  • Window: Days to weeks before irreversibility

Standard Treatment

  • IV Methylprednisolone (Solu-Medrol)
  • 1g daily × 3 days (pulse)
  • Then oral taper
  • ± Cyclophosphamide or Rituximab
data.rightColumn:
Hepatic Risk

With Steroids + Active HBV:
HBV Reactivation → Fulminant Hepatitis

HBV Reactivation Pathophysiology

  • Steroids suppress immune surveillance
  • HBV replication increases unchecked
  • When steroids stop: Immune reconstitution
  • Result: Massive hepatocyte destruction

Risk Factors

  • HBsAg positive (highest risk)
  • High-dose steroids
  • Prolonged immunosuppression
  • No antiviral prophylaxis
Mortality from HBV reactivation: 5-40%

data.title: The Solution: Antiviral Prophylaxis
data.content:
The Bridge Strategy
Initiate antiviral prophylaxis BEFORE immunosuppression to prevent HBV reactivation

Entecavir: The Protective Shield

PropertyDetails
Drug ClassNucleoside analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitor
MechanismInhibits HBV DNA polymerase, suppresses viral replication
EfficacyReduces HBV reactivation risk by >90%
TimingStart ≥1 week before immunosuppression (ideally 2-4 weeks)
DurationContinue 6-12 months after stopping immunosuppression

Protocol for Mr. Ohayon

  1. Immediate: Start Entecavir 0.5mg daily
  2. Urgent: Check HBV DNA viral load
  3. Day 2-3: If stable, proceed with IV Solu-Medrol pulse
  4. Ongoing: Monitor LFTs weekly during steroid therapy
  5. Long-term: Continue Entecavir throughout immunosuppression

data.title: The Diagnostic Question: HSP or EGPA?
data.leftColumn:
Evidence FOR Churg-Strauss (EGPA)

The patient has the "Lung Phenotype" of EGPA

Supporting Features

  • ✓ Severe Asthma – steroid-dependent
  • ✓ Chronic Sinusitis – history of nasal polyps, polypectomy
  • ✓ Historic Eosinophilia – documented peak of 1,800 cells/µL
  • ✓ Lung Opacities – migratory infiltrates on CT

Classic EGPA Triad

  1. Asthma ✓
  2. Eosinophilia ✓ (historically)
  3. Vasculitis ✓
data.rightColumn:
Evidence AGAINST EGPA (Favoring HSP)

The "Renal Phenotype" and serology confirm HSP

Refuting Features

  • ✗ Current Eosinophils: SUPPRESSED/Normal (0.00-0.09 K/µL)
  • ✗ ANCA Negative: Anti-MPO negative (usually positive in renal EGPA)
  • ✓ IgA Spike: 651 mg/dL – specific to HSP, not EGPA
  • ✓ Palpable Purpura: Classic HSP presentation
  • ✓ Renal Pattern: Gross hematuria + nephrotic proteinuria more typical for IgA nephritis
Verdict: HSP (IgA Vasculitis) is primary diagnosis. EGPA ruled out by negative ANCA and suppressed eosinophils.

data.title: Why Eosinophils Are Suppressed
data.content:
The Steroid Effect

Key Insight
Mr. Ohayon has been on Prednisone 20mg since October 30 for HSP

Steroid Effects on Eosinophils

MechanismEffectClinical Implication
Eosinophil apoptosisRapid eosinophil deathCount drops within hours
Bone marrow suppressionReduced productionSustained low counts
SequestrationTissue redistributionPeripheral count falls

Diagnostic Implications

  • Cannot rely on eosinophil count in patient on steroids
  • Historical eosinophilia (1,800/µL) is more informative
  • ANCA remains the key differentiator:
    • EGPA: Usually MPO-ANCA positive (50-70%)
    • HSP: ANCA negative
Teaching Point: Always review historical labs before steroid initiation when evaluating eosinophilic conditions!

data.modifiable:
• Infection control: Respiratory infection was the trigger
  • Early treatment: Higher dose steroids at initial HSP diagnosis
  • Monitoring: Serial creatinine checks after HSP diagnosis
  • Antibiotic stewardship: Avoid nephrotoxic agents
data.nonModifiable:
• Age >60: Higher risk of renal involvement
  • Male sex: Worse renal outcomes in adults
  • Underlying CKD: Even mild baseline impairment
  • HBV status: Complicates treatment options
data.geriatricRisk:
• Polypharmacy: 8+ medications at baseline
  • Frailty: Chronic respiratory disease
  • Reduced renal reserve: Age-related nephron loss
  • Atypical presentations: Less classic purpura distribution
  • Immunosenescence: Altered immune response

data.title: Goals of Care Discussion: The 78-Year-Old with RPGN
data.leftColumn:
Medical Considerations

Prognosis depends on:
• Biopsy findings (crescents vs fibrosis)
• Response to initial therapy
• HBV control on Entecavir

Best Case Scenario

  • Active crescents, minimal fibrosis
  • Good response to steroids
  • Creatinine stabilizes/improves
  • Return to baseline function

Worst Case Scenario

  • Extensive fibrosis (>50%)
  • Progression to dialysis
  • HBV reactivation despite prophylaxis
  • Complications of immunosuppression
data.rightColumn:
Discussion Points with Family

Key Questions to Address:

1. Treatment Intensity

  • Full aggressive treatment vs. comfort-focused
  • Dialysis as bridge vs. destination therapy
  • ICU admission if needed?

2. Quality of Life Priorities

  • What matters most to the patient?
  • Baseline functional status (already limited)
  • Family support system

3. Advance Directives

  • Current code status
  • Healthcare proxy designated?
  • Prior expressed wishes
Time-sensitive: These discussions should happen NOW, before potential deterioration

data.teachingPoints:
1

HSP in the Elderly is Different

While HSP is classically a pediatric disease, adult-onset HSP (especially >65 years) has higher renal involvement rates and worse prognosis. Always screen aggressively for nephritis!

2

Microhematuria is Never Benign in Vasculitis

In Mr. Ohayon, microhematuria at initial HSP diagnosis was the harbinger of RPGN. Early nephrology referral and close creatinine monitoring could have caught the decline earlier.

3

The Dissociation Sign

When infection markers (CRP, WBC) improve but kidney function continues to decline, stop and reconsider the diagnosis. This pattern suggests an autoimmune process independent of infection.

4

Always Screen for HBV Before Immunosuppression

HBsAg, Anti-HBc, and Anti-HBs should be checked in ALL patients before initiating steroids or cytotoxic therapy. Reactivation can be fatal.

5

Elevated IgA + Negative ANCA = IgA Vasculitis

The serological profile is diagnostic. Elevated serum IgA with negative ANCA, ANA, and Anti-GBM strongly supports HSP over other ANCA-associated vasculitides.

data.title: Prognostic Considerations
data.content:
Renal Prognosis in HSP Nephritis

Biopsy FindingPrognosisTreatment Response
Mesangial proliferation onlyExcellentOften resolves spontaneously
Focal/segmental lesionsGoodResponds to steroids
Crescents <50% glomeruliGuardedMay respond to aggressive Rx
Crescents >50% glomeruliPoorHigh risk of ESRD
Fibrosis/sclerosisIrreversibleImmunosuppression futile

Awaiting Biopsy Results

The Biopsy Will Answer:
  • Percentage of glomeruli with crescents
  • Active inflammation vs. chronic scarring
  • IgA deposition pattern (mesangial)
  • Tubular and interstitial damage

Best Case vs. Worst Case

  • Best: Active crescents, minimal fibrosis → Aggressive treatment can salvage function
  • Worst: Extensive fibrosis, >50% crescents → Prepare for dialysis, consider goals of care

data.message1:
RECOGNIZE THE PATTERN
Post-infectious purpura + AKI with active sediment = Think IgA Vasculitis (HSP) Nephritis, not just UTI!
data.message2:
ACT ON WARNING SIGNS
Microhematuria at HSP diagnosis is an early warning of renal involvement. Don't dismiss it – refer to nephrology early.
data.message3:
THE DISSOCIATION SIGN
Improving infection markers + Worsening kidney function = Autoimmune process. Pivot your differential immediately.
data.message4:
SCREEN BEFORE YOU SUPPRESS
HBV status MUST be known before initiating steroids. Entecavir prophylaxis allows safe immunosuppression in HBsAg+ patients.
data.bottomLine: Mr. Ohayon's case illustrates how a common infection can trigger a rare but devastating autoimmune cascade – and how the intersection of RPGN and HBV creates a complex therapeutic challenge requiring meticulous risk-benefit analysis.

data.title: Case Discussion Questions
data.content:
Question 1
At the initial HSP diagnosis (Oct 30), what additional workup should have been done given the microhematuria?
Answer: 24-hour urine for protein, serial creatinine monitoring q48-72h, nephrology consultation, consider higher dose steroids (1mg/kg)
Question 2
What was the key clinical clue that shifted the diagnosis from "UTI with AKI" to "RPGN"?
Answer: The dissociation between improving infection markers (CRP↓) and worsening kidney function (Cr↑). This indicates an autoimmune process independent of infection.
Question 3
Why can't we immediately give high-dose pulse steroids to this patient?
Answer: Patient is HBsAg positive. Pulse steroids without antiviral prophylaxis risk fatal HBV reactivation. Must start Entecavir first and allow 24-48h before initiating immunosuppression.
Question 4
What clinical features argue against EGPA (Churg-Strauss) in this patient?
Answer: Negative ANCA (especially MPO-ANCA), suppressed eosinophils (on steroids, but historical peak only 1,800), markedly elevated IgA (651 mg/dL) specific to HSP not EGPA.
